items.name: Quema del Torito
items.description: This Guatemalan tradition, which began after the Spanish conquest, features a handmade, brightly decorated bull filled with fireworks that, when lit in front of churches, is carried by a person who dances and chases passersby.

items.name: El Carnaval
items.description: This festive celebration, held before Lent, features colorful parades, music, dancing, and costumes, with families and communities filling the streets to enjoy lively performances and playful traditions.

items.name: Danza de los Moros
items.description: A traditional theatrical dance that reenacts the battles between Moors and Christians, performed with elaborate costumes, masks, and choreography to preserve colonial-era cultural heritage.

items.name: Las Posadas
items.description: A nine-night Christmas tradition in which participants reenact Mary and Joseph’s search for lodging, moving in processions between homes and churches while singing carols and sharing food.

items.name: Paseo Cayalá
items.description: Paseo Cayalá is the pedestrian-friendly commercial and cultural center of Ciudad Cayalá in Zone 16 of Guatemala City, featuring Spanish-colonial–inspired architecture, public plazas, shops, restaurants, and cultural spaces designed to foster community interaction and walkability.

items.name: Torre del Reformador
items.description: The Torre del Reformador is a 75-meter tall iron tower inspired by the Eiffel Tower, built in 1935 as a monument to the liberal reformer Justo Rufino Barrios, and is a well-known landmark in Guatemala City located within Parque Reforma.

items.name: Zoológico La Aurora
items.description: Zoológico La Aurora is Guatemala City's main zoo, housing a diverse collection of native and exotic animals within landscaped grounds and offering educational programs and recreational activities for visitors of all ages.

items.name: Catedral de Santiago de Guatemala
items.translation: Cathedral of Saint James of Guatemala
items.description: The Metropolitan Cathedral of Saint James is the main Catholic cathedral in Guatemala City, located in Plaza de la Constitución, renowned for its baroque and neoclassical architecture, religious significance, and historical importance.
